Graphical abstract The LIBs recycle starts with the circular economy, followed by the collection, recycling process and ending with the reutilization of the recycled materials. Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) containing graphite as anode material and LiCoO2, LiMn2O4, and LiNi x Mn y CozO2 as cathode materials are the most used worldwide because of their high energy density, capacitance, durability, and safety. However, such widespread use implies the generation of large amounts of electronic waste. It is estimated that more than 11 million ton of LIBs waste will have been generated by 2030. Battery recycling can contribute to minimizing environmental contamination and reducing production costs through the recovery of high-value raw materials such as lithium, cobalt, and nickel. The most common processes used to recycle spent LIBs are pyrometallurgical, biometallurgical, and hydrometallurgical. Given the current scenario, it is necessary to develop environmentally friendly methods to recycle batteries and synthesize materials with multiple technological applications. This study presents a review of industrial and laboratory processes for recycling spent LIBs and producing materials that can be used in new batteries, energy storage devices, electrochemical sensors, and photocatalytic reactions. Keywords Li-ion batteries Recycling Cathode Battery Hydrometallurgical Pyrometallurgical 1 Introduction The increasing use of electronic products such as laptops and cell phones has brought several benefits to human society. This technological advance, however, has also caused high environmental impacts associated with the inadequate disposal of spent batteries and excessive consumption of natural resources [1,2]. It is estimated that 200,000 t of cathode materials for lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) are produced per year, and production is estimated to reach 6.8 million units by 2035 [3,4]. LIBs are among the most versatile batteries currently in use. Their introduction by Sony® in 1991 was a commercial breakthrough. With advantages such as high power and energy densities, high voltage, and long life cycle, LIBs have replaced Ni-MH and NiCd batteries in laptops, cell phones, cameras, and electric vehicles [5,6]. This study aims to review the composition and reaction mechanism of LIBs, the main recycling processes and applications of recycled materials, and the challenges that remain to be addressed in LIBs recycling. 1.1 Composition of LIBs The composition of LIBs is shown in Fig. 1 . The cathode is composed of a metallic material pressed into an aluminum current collector. Commercial LIBs use lithium compounds, generally oxides such as lithium-cobalt oxide (LiCoO2), lithium-manganese oxide (LiMn2O4), lithium-nickel oxide (LiNiO2), lithium-nickel–cobalt-manganese oxide (LiNiMnCoO2), and lithium iron phosphate (LiFePO4). The main goal of using mixed oxides is to obtain cheap and environmentally friendly materials while maintaining high electrochemical performance. LiMn2O4 has high stability and low cost, but its low specific capacity narrows its applicability. LiNiO2 is a cheap material with high specific capacity, but it has safety limitations, having to be operated at low temperatures to avoid thermal decomposition. The most commonly used cathode material is LiCoO2 because of its good performance, high specific energy density, and durability [6]. 1.1.1 Lithium cobalt oxide (LCO) LiCoO2 exists in two forms, HT-LiCoO2 and LT-LiCoO2. The distinction between the two forms resides in their morphology. HT-LiCoO2 has a hexagonal structure belonging to the trigonal group with space group R3̅m and is obtained at temperatures above 400 °C; hence it is named HT (high-temperature). LT-LiCoO2 has a cubic structure of the spinel-type with space group Fd3̅m and is obtained at temperatures below 400 °C; hence it is referred to as low-temperature (LT). The lamellar structure of HT-LiCoO2 ensures good diffusion of lithium ions, providing high energy efficiency and stability during charge–discharge processes, which makes it an interesting cathode material [7]. Its discharge reaction is given by Eq. (1). (1) C y + L i C o O 2 ↔ L i x C y + L i 1 - x C o O 2 LCO was released in 1991 as the first metal oxide in LIBs. This type of cathode is composed of LiCoO2 and often used in conjunction with a graphite (C6) anode. Given their high specific energy density (150–190 Wh/kg), LCO batteries are a common choice for portable electronic devices, such as cell phones, tablets, and laptops. Their durability of about 1000 charge-discharge cycles makes them compatible with these devices. The main disadvantage of LCO batteries is their low safety. The cathode has low stability, being flammable at temperatures above 150 °C. Another problem associated with LCO batteries is the limited commercial availability of cobalt worldwide, as this material is mostly extracted by a single country, the Democratic Republic of the Congo [8]. 1.1.2 Lithium manganese oxide (LMO) LMO batteries contain manganese, a relatively more abundant and environmentally friendly material than cobalt. First marketed in 1996, LMO batteries were developed as a safer and cheaper alternative to LCO batteries [9]. The three-dimensional spinel structure of LiMn2O4 favors the flow of ions between electrodes, resulting in low internal resistance and a longer life (1000–1500 cycles). Compared with LCO batteries, however, LMO batteries have lower energy density. When combined with graphite, the system delivers a specific energy density of 100–140 Wh/kg. Manganese oxide has high thermal stability. Consequently, LMO batteries are much safer, becoming flammable only at temperatures above 250 °C. This combination of properties makes LMO batteries suitable for use in power tools, medical devices, and electric bicycles [9]. 1.1.3 Lithium iron phosphate (LFP) The major constituent of the cathode of LFP batteries is LiFePO4. Because of their durability, safety, and production from abundant and environmentally friendly materials, LFP batteries were considered promising when first marketed in 1999. Current LFP batteries last about 2000 charge-discharge cycles. Industry projections indicate an even longer service life. These advantages made LFP batteries an interesting candidate for use in electric vehicles. However, their specific energy (90–140 Wh/kg) is not advantageous compared with that of other LIBs. Although LFP batteries played a pioneering role in the electric vehicle industry, they have achieved greater success in electric bicycles. This material also shows great potential for use in energy supply systems [9]. 1.1.4 Lithium nickel cobalt aluminum oxide (NCA) NCA cathodes were introduced to the market in 1999. The material consists of mixed oxides of LiNiCoAlO2. In general, these cathodes contain 80% (w/w) nickel, 15% (w/w) cobalt, and 5% (w/w) aluminum. Such a mixture guarantees a low dependence on cobalt as compared with LCO cathodes. The greatest advantage of NCA batteries is their high specific energy density (200–250 Wh/kg), which, associated with their ability to withstand about 1500 complete cycles, makes these cells promising for several applications, including electric vehicles [9,10]. NCA batteries became even more popular when used by Tesla® in their vehicles. Popularization resulted in a cost advantage, making the production process accessible to the general industry [11]. 1.1.5 Lithium nickel manganese cobalt oxide (NMC) The cathodes of NMC batteries are formed by LiNiMnCoO2. Although NMC batteries have a long life cycle (about 2000 cycles) compared with NCA, their energy density is relatively lower, in the range of 140–200 Wh/kg. Nickel, manganese, and cobalt ratios can be altered to obtain different properties and provide customized solutions for specific applications [9–11]. Studies have found that variations in the amount of cobalt, nickel, and manganese may influence the electrochemical and thermal properties of the material. In this type of cathode, oxidation and reduction processes are mainly attributed to the redox pair Ni2+/Ni3+, which is responsible for the high capacity of the material. A high amount of nickel reduces the thermal stability of NMC batteries. Oxidation of Co3+ to Co4+ may occur after nickel oxidation. The presence of cobalt is mainly related to increased conductivity. Mn4+ ions do not participate in electronic processes, having solely a structural function, promoting long life cycles [12]. First marketed in 2004, NMC batteries currently dominate the electric vehicle market and are also used in portable devices, power tools, and medical devices. The anode manufacturing process is similar to that of the cathode: the material is pressed into a sheet of copper that acts as current collector (Fig. 1). Graphite is the dominant anode material in commercial LIBs, as it provides efficient insertion and removal accommodation of lithium ions, high charge and discharge rates, and high contact surface between electrode and electrolyte. Graphite can be recovered from battery waste and used as a precursor of reduced graphene oxide, whose electronic properties are promising [13–15]. The electrochemical performance of the anode is influenced by many factors, including particle size, surface area, interface, and structural organization. Nanostructured materials such as wires, rods, and spheres have shown promising results. Currently, some metal alloy intercalation oxides are gaining prominence, particularly metallic monoxides (MnO, CoO, NiO, and CuO) and metallic dioxides (TiO2, SnO2, and RuO2) [6]. Another important component of LIBs is the electrolyte, responsible for the transport of charges from one electrode to another. It is the electrolyte that determines how fast energy can be released, controlling the rate of mass flow within the battery. LIBs electrolytes are usually salts dissolved in organic solvents (non-aqueous or aprotic) with high dielectric constants [16]. The most common solvents are propylene carbonate, ethylene carbonate, and dimethyl sulfoxide, all capable of dissolving various lithium salts. The electrolyte contains lithium salts to ensure ionic conductivity. The most common salts are LiPF6, LiBF4, LiCF3SO3, and Li(SO2CF3)2. Additives are often used to enhance the properties of electrolytes, acting by facilitating the formation of the electrolyte-solid interface, protecting cathode agents, stabilizing salts, increasing cell safety, and aiding the deposition of lithium ions [16]. The separator is a permeable membrane placed between the battery anode and cathode. Its main function is to prevent physical contact between electrodes and allow ionic transport through the electrolyte. Most battery separators on the market are porous films made of polymeric materials, such as polyethylene or polypropylene. The separator also acts as a safety device; if the cell overheats, the porous film melts and irreversibly seals the electrodes [17]. LIBs are susceptible to external effects that can damage the electrolyte and cause safety issues such as increased flammability. A casing is used to protect and maintain the physical integrity of batteries. Aluminum was initially used as casing because of its high resistance to environmental factors, mainly moisture and oxygen. Nowadays, polymeric materials such as polypropylene have replaced aluminum as the material of choice because they offer higher malleability and chemical resistance. Steels are the most common coating materials for LIBs. The excellent chemical resistance and corrosion protection provided by steel ensures both the chemical and physical integrity of the battery while retaining its components under pressure, thereby preventing battery collapse under adverse environmental conditions [18]. 1.2 Reaction mechanism LIBs use a mechanism of intercalation and deintercalation of lithium ions between electrodes, known as the rocking chair mechanism. During the charging process (non-spontaneous), lithium ions move from the cathode structure, migrating through the electrolyte and intercalating into the anode structure. As the metal (M) at the cathode oxidizes, electrons flow through the external circuit and are consumed at the anode. During the discharge process (spontaneous), the anode releases electrons, which flow through an external circuit, produce energy, and are consumed at the cathode during the reduction reaction. This process is described in Eq. (2) [6–19]. (2) C y + L i M O 2 ↔ L i x C y + L i 1 - x M O 2 The mechanism is limited by the intercalation/deintercalation rate of lithium ions in the host matrix. It follows three main steps [20]: (1) Diffusion and/or migration of solvated lithium ions in the electrolyte. (2) Desolvation and insertion of lithium ions in structural vacancies. (3) Diffusion of lithium ions in the host network. Even though there is charge transfer between cathode and anode, the M−O bond does not break because it has high energy. Intercalation of cations in the host network must occur to maintain electroneutrality [15]. The mechanism of charge and discharge of LIBs is represented in Fig. 2 . 1.3 Economic aspects The most common metals in LIBs cathodes are cobalt, nickel, lithium, aluminum, copper, and manganese. Such metals, when inadequately disposed of, may contaminate the environment and accumulate in the human body. Once absorbed by the body, these metals can cause various health problems. Cobalt and nickel are known to be carcinogens and mutagens [21]. Cobalt, in particular, is of importance because of its scarcity, industrial use, and high economical value. China is the world's leading cobalt consumer. More than 80% of cobalt is used in the rechargeable battery industry. According to the London Metal Exchange, the price of cobalt in 2020 was US$52,365 per tonne [22]. Inadequate disposal of battery waste produces negative environmental, health, and economic impacts. LIBs contain toxic and flammable compounds as solvents. A circular economy of spent LIBs may lead to the reduction of raw material consumption, prevention of environmental pollution, and recovery of high-value metals [6]. Circular economy is an alternative economic model to linear economy; the latter is based on raw material extraction, manufacture, use, and disposal of products at the end of their life cycle. Geissdoerfer (2017) defined circular economy as “a regenerative system in which the input and waste of resources, the emission and leakage of energy are minimized by decelerating, closing and narrowing the material and energy circuits. This can be achieved through long-term design, maintenance, repair, reuse, remanufacturing, reconditioning and recycling” [23]. In 2017, the World Bank published the report “The growing role of minerals and metals for a low carbon future,” warning how low-carbon technologies (such as LIBs) can be affected by the high consumption of mineral and metallic resources. LIBs recycling is an interesting alternative to obtain metals as opposed to mineral extraction, contributing to minimizing the deficit between device consumption and production [24]. According to “The lithium-ion battery life cycle report 2021,” by the Circular Energy Storage consultancy in London, in 2020, the volume of LIBs available for recycling was 188,000 t, 80% of which originated from portable devices. The transportation sector was the second largest, mainly because of the use of LIBs in bicycles and electric scooters [25]. The Circular Energy Storage consultancy predicted that the LIBs market will continue to grow. In 2030, it is estimated that light and heavy electric vehicles will correspond to 77% of the total installed capacity of LIBs. In 2019, electric vehicles accounted for only 19% of the total capacity, and, in 2010, for less than 1%. It is estimated that 799,000 and 820,000 t of LIBs will be reused and recycled, respectively, in 2030 [25]. The application of green chemistry principles in the circular economy model is fundamental for sustainable economic development. Fig. 3 is the schematic representation of the circular economy for LIBs. Environmental and sustainable aspects of LIBs recycling LIBs consumption has grown worldwide, motivated by an increasing demand for electronic devices that are able to store as much energy as possible and withstand a large number of charge–discharge cycles without generating greenhouse gas emissions [26–29]. Batteries containing graphite as anode material and lithium-MO x (M = Co, Ni, Mn) as cathode material are the most widely used because of their high energy density, capacitance, durability, and safety [30–32]. It is estimated that, by 2025, 400,000 t of cathode active materials and 50,000 t of anode active materials will be needed to meet the global demand for new batteries, whereas secondary production would require only 28 t of recycled LIBs [30]. LIBs from electric vehicles [33]. The natural resources used in battery manufacture are finite and have a high cost [34]. For primary production by conventional methods, it would be necessary to extract 250 t of spodumene or 750 t of mineral-rich brine to produce 1 t of lithium [33]. The processing of such large quantities of raw materials implies considerable environmental impacts [33]. Brine extraction, for example, involves drilling brine deposits and pumping the mineral-rich solution to the surface [J8]. This activity consumes a large amount of groundwater: 1,900 t of water are necessary to extract 1 t of lithium [33]. Farmers in the surrounding area are directly affected and may need to import water from other regions [33], as has occurred in the Salar de Atacama in Chile. In this important lithium-producing region, 65% of local water resources are consumed by mining activities [33]. Furthermore, production of battery cathodes and anodes from extracted raw material releases polluting gases, contributing to the greenhouse effect [34]. It is estimated that battery recycling has the potential to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 81%–98% and SOx emissions by up to 100% during cathode material production [35–37]. In addition to the environmental impacts associated with LIBs manufacture, there are also problems related to the inadequate disposal and storage of battery waste, which is highly explosive because of the reactivity of electrode components [38,39]. The scarcity and high cost of battery materials are current concerns in the global market. According to the London Metal Exchange, cobalt and lithium hydroxide, two materials used in the production of LIBs cathodes for electric vehicles, cost US$92,115.33 and US$80,600.00 per tonne, respectively [40]; Cobalt is sold at high prices in the global market because most cobalt reserves are located in politically unstable countries, such as the Democratic Republic of the Congo [41,42]. Extraction of this raw material is linked to a number of ethical and social issues, including child labor [34,41]. 2 Recycling processes Recycling aims to recover components of depleted batteries for reuse in battery production. Cobalt, nickel, and lithium, found in the cathode, are the main targets of recovery because of their high economic value. LIBs recycling can be divided into three steps: pretreatment, metal extraction, and final product application [43,44]. 2.1 Pretreatment This step consists in the separation of active materials from other components. Pretreatment contributes to later stages of recycling, as it reduces impurities and energy consumption, thereby increasing the recovery efficiency of materials of interest. First, the battery is fully discharged to prevent the occurrence of spontaneous combustion, which is caused by short circuit between electrodes and subsequent ignition of the electrolyte. In an industrial process, battery discharge is achieved by immersing LIBs in a NaCl solution [43]. The next steps comprise disassembly, classification of LIBs components (density, solubility, shape, size), separation, dissolution, and heat treatment [44]. The most common procedures are mechanical separation and dissolution in organic solvents [45]. It is at this stage that metallic and plastic casings are removed, generally by crushing, sieving, flotation, gravity separation, or magnetic separation. Crushing is carried out in low-temperature environments with inert atmospheres for safety reasons. During this process, gases such as dimethyl carbonate, ethyl methyl carbonate, and carbon dioxide may be released. Crushing may alter particle size and component distribution, negatively influencing the surface properties of electrode materials for subsequent separation processes [46]. Sieving is commonly used to separate LIBs components. Active electrode materials have small fractions (<1 mm) that can be separated from plastics, separators, aluminum sheets, and copper sheets, which form large fractions (>1 mm). By combining crushing and sieving, it is possible to separate several components into a controllable range of particle sizes, facilitating subsequent leaching steps [47]. Another process used to separate materials on the basis of physical properties is flotation. Flotation is based on the difference in wettability between cathode and anode materials: the former are hydrophilic and the latter hydrophobic [48]. Components with different densities can be separated by the action of gravity, whereas magnetic impurities such as iron can be separated using magnetic separation. Separation of active materials from current collectors is achieved by immersing electrodes in NMP solution under ultrasonication, dissolving the binder. Studies reported that the dissolution efficiency of polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) in N-methyl-2-pyrrolidine (NMP) is 99% [49,50]. Processes using ultrasound, room temperature, and short treatment time were found to be ecofriendly alternatives to conventional NMP dissolution conditions (e.g., 100 °C, 1 h) [49,50]. Removal efficiency is defined as the percentage ratio of the weight of separated cathode materials to the total weight of separated and lost cathode materials adhered to the aluminum sheet. The main parameters affecting removal efficiency are nature of the solvent, temperature, ultrasound time, and power. Dissolution efficiency increases according to following order of solvents: ethanol < dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) < N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) < dimethylacetamide (DMAC) < NMP [44]. In an innovative experiment, Pant et al. (2017) found that organic binders could be removed under the optimal conditions of 90 °C and 20 min. Copper (anode) and aluminum (cathode) substrates were separated and then washed with water. Subsequently, the remaining solution was refluxed for 30 min and filtered to remove carbon and other impurities. Citrus fruit juice is an environmentally friendly agent to remove organic binders. The acid in citrus juice can dissolve aluminum sheets, resulting in aluminum loss [51]. Binders attaching active materials to current collectors can also be removed by heat treatment. Heat treatment and calcination were used to release electrode materials from current collectors and burn carbon and binders. The electrode materials were released from aluminum current collectors during pretreatment, and materials containing Li and Co were concentrated via a two-step heat treatment (oven-drying at 300–500 °C for 1 h). The active materials of lithium cobalt oxide (LCO) cathode were obtained by burning carbon and binders at temperatures of 500–900 °C for 0.5–2 h. PVDF and carbon dust in cathode materials were eliminated with high-temperature calcination after LCO was initially separated from the aluminum sheet [49]. Dry powder was initially heated at 450 °C for 2 h and then to 600 °C for 5 h. LCO cathode materials were separated using a two-stage heat treatment of spent LIBs. The first heat treatment step was conducted at 150–500 °C for 1 h to burn binders and organic additives. The second heat treatment was carried out at 700–900 °C for 1 h to remove carbon and unburned organic residues. After drying at 60 °C for 24 h, thermal pretreatment was performed to eliminate carbon and PVDF in cathode active materials. Cathode active materials from spent batteries were calcined at 700 °C for 5 h in a muffle and cooled to room temperature [52,53]. Yang et al. (2016) used heat treatment as an alternative for separating active materials from copper/aluminum sheets. Heat treatment of the cathode and anode of spent LIBs in a high purity nitrogen atmosphere significantly improved the recovery efficiency of valuable metals. The binder can be completely removed by maintaining treatment temperature between the decomposition temperature of PVDF binders and the melting point of current collectors. Thus, aluminum and copper collectors can be completely separated from active materials with little contamination and recycled following a simple washing procedure. Heat treatment also alters the molecular structure of cathode active materials and reduces the charge of transition metal ions, which is beneficial for the recovery of transition metals by leaching [49]. Some pretreatment methods used in industrial LIBs recycling processes were mentioned in previous sections. However, there is not much literature information on the pretreatment technologies used by LIBs recycling companies. Some articles summarized pretreatment methods used by industrial companies, such as Batrec, Recupyl, and Retriev [54,55]. A considerable number of studies described pretreatment methods that are unlikely to be adopted by LIBs recycling companies, partly because they are limited to laboratory-scale experiments and only applicable to certain types of LIBs. For instance, it is industrially advantageous to use inert atmosphere as a stabilization strategy to achieve high yields instead of a laboratory-scale electrochemical discharge method. Furthermore, many reports focus on a specific LIBs cathode composition (e.g., LCO or LFP). It is economically impractical to separate LIBs according to their cathode composition; thus, pretreatment methods that have proven effective for LIBs with mixed cathode composition would be promising for industrial use. The purpose of pretreatment is to reduce impurities and energy consumption. Some pretreatment methods may, however, contaminate the component of interest of a specific recycling process. For instance, introducing salts to a discharge solution can cause salt species to contaminate electrode powders, and these impure species need to be removed before metal recovery or direct recycling of the cathode active material [44]. 2.2 Metal extraction Metal extraction can be performed using different methods, the most common of which are pyrometallurgical, hydrometallurgical, and biometallurgical processes. 2.2.1 Direct regeneration Direct recycling of LIBs, a recent technology compared with pyrometallurgical and hydrometallurgical recycling, allows obtaining electroactive materials by regeneration of exhausted batteries. The main advantages are its non-destructive nature, low consumption of chemicals and energy, and reduced generation of secondary waste [56]. Lithiation is a direct recycling approach that consists of adding lithium to the spent material to restore its stoichiometry and original properties. Several methods have been developed, such as solid-state lithiation, electrochemical lithiation, and solvothermal lithiation. Liang and colleagues (2020) performed direct regeneration of LiFePO4 from LIBs used in electric buses. Inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) revealed that the material had a Li/Fe/P molar ratio of 5.53:4.77:3.97. The stoichiometric state (1:1:1) was reestablished by adding salts of these elements, and regenerated Li FePO4was obtained by heat treatment at 650 °C for 10 h under an N2 stream [57]. Meng and colleagues (2022) developed a method for direct recycling of the anode graphite and LiFePO4 cathode of LIBs. A major advantage of their process is the possibility of recycling anode and cathode materials simultaneously, which contributes to reducing waste generation. The graphite-LiFePO4 hybrid material, named RGLFP was obtained after mixing, grinding, and drying the specimens [58]. Direct recycling is of utmost importance for achieving a circular economy, as it represents an efficient route to recover materials that can be applied in new batteries. 2.2.2 Pyrometallurgical processes The most common pyrometallurgical metal extraction process is smelting. Smelting occurs by heating spent batteries to temperatures above the melting point. This facilitates separation of metals in the liquid phase, leading to the formation of immiscible fused layers. Smelting results in the formation of alloy products (such as cobalt) and slag (such as Li2O and Li2CO3). Additives composed of Al2O3, CaO, MgO, or SiO2 can be used to facilitate slag formation in spent batteries [59]. At this stage, lithium normally occurs in the slag phase, and, to avoid lithium dispersion, deionized water and alkaline slag can be added to the mixture. Thus, depending on the nature of the components used, products with different purities and compositions can be obtained by controlling the atmosphere and temperature of heat treatment. The resulting alloys and slag require further recovery steps. Currently, smelting is performed by companies such as Sony, Umicore, Accurec, Onto, and Inmetco [60]. In pyrometallurgical processes, high temperatures are applied to separate and purify metals in spent batteries. Chemical reactions predominate at high temperatures and physical processes (phase transition and structural changes) at low temperatures. Incineration and pyrolysis are other examples of pyrometallurgical methods. The main difference between incineration and pyrolysis is the environment in which they occur. Incineration takes place in the presence of air or oxygen. This step ensures the burning of organic compounds, binders, and plastic wrappings at high temperatures. Pyrolysis takes place in the absence of oxygen, in an inert atmosphere or under vacuum. In this step, spent batteries are subjected to temperatures that result in battery decomposition and, consequently, complete discharge, reducing the risk of adverse reactions of lithium with moisture, thereby ensuring safety. During pyrolysis, organic materials are decomposed and the cathode active material remains as solid waste. As a result, it is possible to recycle the active material in subsequent steps. Pyrolysis facilitates the recovery of current collectors and electrolytes, which can be achieved by condensation [61]. Some of the advantages of heat treatment processes include ease of operation and low cost. However, such processes may contribute to air pollution and high energy consumption. Heat treatment is often used in combination with other processes for the recycling of spent LIBs. Fig. 4 is a schematic representation of the pyrometallurgical process. 2.2.3 Hydrometallurgical processes (1) Leaching Metals may be extracted via leaching with inorganic or organic acids. Inorganic acids are frequently used for leaching the cathode material because of their high leaching rates. The most common inorganic acids are hydrochloric, sulfuric, and nitric acids. There are disadvantages, however, such as emission of SO3, Cl2, and NO x gases and generation of acidic wastewater [62]. Organic acids are weaker and more thermally stable, cause lower environmental impacts, and form strong chelates. This set of characteristics allows organic acids to play an important role in metal dissolution through acidolysis and complexolysis [63]. Some of the most common organic acids are citric acid, ascorbic acid, succinic acid, oxalic acid, tartaric acid, dl-malic acid, formic acid, iminodiacetic acid, lactic acid, and acid acetic [64]. Previous studies have demonstrated that it is possible to achieve efficient recovery of cobalt and lithium from LIBs using organic acids, as summarized in Table 1 . High cobalt and lithium leaching efficiencies are obtained by varying the organic acid and parameters that interfere with dissolution efficiency, such as acid concentration, leaching temperature, solid/liquid ratio, quantity of reducing agent, and leaching time. Some transition metal oxides, such as Co3+ and Mn3+, are insoluble, requiring their reduction, such as to Mn2+ and Co2+. By decreasing the valence of metals, it is possible to weaken chemical bonds and increase the rate of dissolution [63]. Reducing agents such as H2O2, NaHSO3, Na2SO3, Na2S2O3, glucose, ascorbic acid, and even Phytolacca americana tea residues are commonly used for leaching [65]. Fig. 5 is a schematic representation of the hydrometallurgical process. (2) Lithium recovery Lithium recovery from LIBs can be carried out via selective and non-selective hydrometallurgical processes. In non-selective methods, the cathode material is leached and the metals are ionized and remain available in solution. The selective method is widely used for LiFePO4 cathode recycling, whereby Li+ ions are extracted in solution and phosphorus and iron remain in the solid residue. Jo et al. (2019) recovered lithium by a traditional hydrometallurgical process. The cathode material was leached in 1.0 mol/L H2SO4, affording lithium ions and transition metal ions in solution. Transition metals were separated by precipitation with sodium hydroxide. Li+ ions in the supernatant solution were precipitated in the form of Li2CO3 by CO2 bubbling [67]. Tao et al. (2019) recovered lithium by oxidative activation of LiFeO4 cathodes at 600 °C. The method has some advantages, such as reduction of impurities, increase of specific surface area, and destabilization of the olivine structure. The structural, morphological, and elemental modifications that occur during heat treatment optimize the leaching process, resulting in high efficiency and low acid consumption. Leaching of the resulting product in sulfuric acid afforded lithium in solution and iron in the form of solid residue. Lithium present in the supernatant was recovered as Li3PO4 by addition of NaOH and Na3PO4 [68]. Makuza and collaborators (2021) performed the carbothermic reduction of LiCoO2, LiMn2O4, and LiNiO2 from spent LIBs using anode graphite as carbon source. After thermal treatment, samples were leached in an ultrasonic bath with ultrapure water and CO2 addition for lithium recovery [69]. Recently, Zheng and collaborators (2022) reported an important method for the recovery of lithium from LIBs. The authors performed selective extraction of lithium ions in leachate by using imidazolium ionic liquid as extractor. After three stages, the lithium extraction efficiency was greater than 90% and that of transition metals was less than 4% [70]. (3) Chemical precipitation Chemical precipitation is applied to produce valuable metal compounds that are insoluble in leachate solutions. Generally, precipitants such as sodium hydroxide, oxalic acid, ammonium oxalate, phosphoric acid, and sodium carbonate are used. These compounds react with cobalt and lithium ions to form insoluble precipitates, such as cobalt hydroxide, cobalt oxalate, lithium phosphate, and lithium carbonate [71–73]. Eqs. (3) and (4) describe reactions that may occur with oxalate. (3) 7 H 2 C 2 O 4 + 2 L i C o O 2 ( s ) → 2 L i H C 2 O 4 + 2 C o H C 2 O 4 ( s ) + 4 H 2 O + 2 C O 2 (4) 4 H 2 C 2 O 4 + 2 L i C o O 2 ( s ) → L i 2 C 2 O 4 + 2 C o C 2 O 4 ( s ) + 4 H 2 O + 2 C O 2 Precipitation can also be used to remove impurities (e.g., iron, copper, and aluminum). Parameters such as pH and temperature directly influence chemical precipitation and, therefore, need to be carefully controlled. Chemical precipitation is widely applied because it does not require expensive equipment, being simple and low cost. The main factors to be considered are the selection of precipitants and determination of ideal conditions to avoid precipitate dissolution. (4) Solvent extraction One of the main objectives of LIBs recycling is to obtain pure metals or metallic compounds. The coexistence of various metal ions in leachate affects the recycling of pure metals. Single-step precipitation is a challenge when the precipitation pH range of different metals overlap. Leachate solution must undergo several separation steps, such as solvent extraction. Solvent extraction is a liquid–liquid separation method based on differences in the relative solubility of compounds in two immiscible liquids. Although it is difficult to separate compounds with similar functional groups via solvent extraction, the method is highly reliable and widely used [47]. The effect of equilibrium pH on metal extraction is important in solvent extraction. For example, di(2-ethylhexyl) phosphoric acid (D2EHPA) is indicated for extracting copper and manganese ions, but its cobalt selectivity is low at pH 2.2–3.0 [47]. Bis(2,4,4-trimethylpentyl)phosphinic acid (sold under the commercial name Cyanex 272) is another viable metal extractor for battery recycling. Cyanex 272 allows the separation of nickel (at pH 0.5–1) in Ni-MH batteries and LIBs and that of lithium cobalt (at pH 0.5–3) in LIBs [45]. Extractors can also be used in combination for selective extraction of various metals. Cyanex 272 was used with Acorga M5640 for separation of cobalt, nickel, and copper in LIBs [74]. Solvent extraction allows the recovery of metals with high purity and high efficiency and is conducted at room temperature in a short time. Some disadvantages include process complexity and high solvent costs. Studies on solvent extraction have focused on the development of cheaper solvents and cyclical use of solvents. Electrodeposition and recrystallization may also be used and combined to achieve greater recovery efficiency. (5) Electrodeposition Electrodeposition has very high metal recovery rates, low environmental impact, and low energy consumption. The process is limited in dilute solutions, as high electrical resistance and concentration polarization reduce its efficiency. Electroplating is commonly used in conjunction with other recovery techniques. Schiavi et al. (2019) proposed the use of acidic dissolution followed by selective precipitation as a route to recover metals from spent LIBs. Precipitated metals in the form of carbonates constituted the electrolytic solution, which allowed electrochemical recovery of cobalt, nickel, and manganese. Factors such as electrolytic bath pH, composition, charge density, reaction time, substrate, and parallel reactions directly influence the structure and morphology of materials synthesized by electrochemical techniques [75]. Freitas et al. (2009) investigated the parameters used in the electrodeposition of metals obtained by hydrometallurgical recycling of spent LIBs. It was observed that the structure and charging efficiency of recycled cobalt electrodeposits depend on the applied charge density and electrolytic bath pH. At pH 2.7, Co2+ reduction occurred concomitantly with H+ reduction, resulting in lower charging efficiency than at pH 5.4. At pH 5.4, electrodeposit formation occurred mainly by three-dimensional growth of films, with face-centered cubic structures, whereas, at pH 2.7, lateral growth and hexagonal structures were favored [76]. Freitas et al. (2010) used acid leaching of copper current collector and LIBs cathode material (LiCoO2) for the synthesis of copper/cobalt multilayers, with glassy carbon, aluminum, and platinum electrodes as substrates. The authors studied the influence of charge density and electrolytic bath pH on film growth and morphology. At pH 2.7, there was an instantaneous two-dimensional growth of films with homogeneous morphology. At pH 5.4, the nucleation rate was slow and growth tended toward a progressive mechanism, forming films with a large number of active sites, indicating three-dimensional growth [77]. Wang et al. (2021) proposed an electrochemical LiCoO2 recycling route from spent LIBs. The authors used a single-step process of suspension electrolysis with NH4HCO3, (NH4)2SO3, and NaF as electrolytes. The method allowed the leaching and resynthesis of the material in a single step; 95.3% of Li and 88.6% of spent cell phone batteries were recovered [78]. Although the reported processes exhibit high recovery values, there is still room for improvement, especially in previous steps, as the presence of impurities in electrolyte solutions decreases the efficiency of electrodeposition. (6) Metallurgical solvothermal processes Another alternative to inorganic acids is deep eutectic solvents. These solvents are formed by a mixture of two or more compounds, a hydrogen bond donor and a hydrogen bond receptor, that have a lower melting point than the melting points of the individual compounds. These liquids are easy to purify and synthesize, inexpensive, and commonly produced from natural products. These characteristics contribute to the development of safer and more environmentally friendly routes. Studies have shown that deep eutectic solvents are capable of solubilizing metal oxides and can be used for leaching metals as an alternative to acids [79]. Furthermore, these compounds have a wide electrochemical potential window, which allows the use of electrochemical techniques for metal purification and refining [80]. The most common deep eutectic solvents comprise choline chloride and other substances. Previous studies demonstrated that the use of carboxylic acids as secondary components allows the recovery of various metal oxides, such as iron, copper, and zinc. Tran et al. (2019) [81] found that the use of chloride in conjunction with ethylene glycol for leaching (24 h, 150 °C) afforded a 90% recovery of cobalt and lithium from spent LIBs. Wang et al. (2020) [82] obtained even better results when using urea instead of ethylene glycol, recovering 95% of cobalt and lithium. One of the disadvantages of this process is the low kinetic rate of the reaction, which may compromise its applicability on an industrial scale. However, the development of faster processes has been studied. For example, a less aggressive leaching process (citric acid, 1 h, 40 °C) provided 85% recovery of cobalt and lithium [83]. Although deep eutectic solvents can dissolve metal oxides, these materials have not yet been fully explored by the LIBs recycling industry. 2.2.4 Biometallurgical processes Biometallurgy is an emerging interdisciplinary process that combines chemistry, biology, and metallurgy. Biometallurgy of spent secondary batteries has attracted great attention among researchers. The performance of biometallurgical processes depends mainly on the ability of microorganisms to convert insoluble solid compounds into soluble forms [84–86]. Chemolithotrophic and acidophilic bacteria such as Acidithiobacillus ferrooxidans are commonly used for leaching. The reaction is generally maintained at 30 °C and pH 2.5. Cobalt and lithium leaching efficiencies are quite low, even with long reaction times [86]. Xin et al. (2016) obtained lithium, cobalt, nickel, and manganese by bioleaching the cathodes of LIBs from electric vehicles. Cathode materials consisted of LiFeP4, LiMn2O4, and LiNi x Co y Mn(1- x - y )O2, and the bioleaching agents were the sulfur-oxidizing bacterium Acidithiobacillus thiooxidans (At) and the iron-oxidizing bacterium Leptospirillum ferriphilum (Lf). Three bioleaching systems were studied: sulfur–At, pyrite–Lf, and mixed culture. The sulfur–At system afforded the best results; 98% Li was recovered from LiFePO4, and 95% Li and 96% Mn were recovered from LiMn2O4 [84]. To increase the efficiency of cobalt bioleaching from spent LIBs, Zeng et al. (2013) catalyzed the biometallurgical process by addition of Ag+ ions. LiCoO2 was used as cathode material with A. ferrooxidans in the presence or not of AgNO3. A maximum cobalt recovery of 92.2% was achieved using AgNO3 (0.02 g/L). In the absence of Ag+, however, the recovery efficiency was 41.3% [87]. Biometallurgical processes are conducted under mild conditions and have low energy consumption compared with conventional methods, representing an environmentally friendly technology. However, slow kinetics is a serious disadvantage of biometallurgy for industrial applications. Fig. 6 is a schematic representation of the biometallurgical process. 2.2.5 Processes comparison The major recycling processes for LIBs comprise a common pretreatment step. This step is necessary to safely disassemble the batteries, recover valuable organic components, and facilitate separation of active substances from electrodes. Pretreatment and stabilization methods differ among leading recycling companies [88]. For example, retriev technologies (Toxco) subjects batteries to a crushing process under a stream of water, nitrogen, or both. Batrec and Recupyl, on the other hand, apply an inert atmosphere (Ar and CO2) during crushing to avoid violent reactions. Umicore processes batteries in ultra-high-temperature furnaces that are intrinsically safe. Battery discharge in saline solutions can also be applied as a stabilization method [89]. Most recycling processes used by these companies differ in the next step, that is, recovery and purification of valuable components from spent batteries. The two most common methods are metallurgical: pyrometallurgical routes involve the use of high temperatures and hydrometallurgical routes comprise chemical reactions in solutions at low temperatures [61]. Industrial pyrometallurgical operations have high efficiency but also major drawbacks. Except for the furnace-based single-step technology developed by Umicore, most commercial processes have very high energy consumption. Accurec, for example, relies on vacuum ovens to reduce pretreatment processes and energy costs. Companies such as Batrec, Inmetco, and Sumitomo-Sony follow a more conventional route consisting of pretreatment and calcination at 1000 °C. SNAM applies pyrolysis followed by distillation and metal refining [90–92]. Industrial hydrometallurgical technologies, such as those applied by Recupyl, Accurec, and Toxco, conventionally employ inorganic acids for metal leaching because of their high leaching efficiency. However, because inorganic acids are associated with environmental hazards, there is a trend toward their substitution by organic acids, mainly in processes that combine hydrometallurgical and pyrometallurgical techniques, such as those used by Umicore, Glencore, and Akkuser [92,93]. Pyrometallurgical and hydrometallurgical processes start with a similar pretreatment step, after which they differ. Hydrometallurgy allows for direct recovery of copper and aluminum current collectors. Pyrometallurgical processes lead to the loss of copper, aluminum, and lithium as a mixed alloy in the slag. These materials can still be recovered from the slag by a hydrometallurgical process, but the associated cost and energy requirements make this additional step less attractive. The most important difference between pyrometallurgical and hydrometallurgical technologies is the operating temperature. Hydrometallurgical routes have low energy consumption and therefore can be performed on a small scale by local companies, precluding the need for long-distance transportation for battery recycling [94,95]. Both processes affect the morphology of the cathode material. Hydrometallurgical methods, for instance, use an acid solution to dissolve the cathode to its constituent ions. This characteristic may be considered an advantage of hydrometallurgical processes. The resulting ions in the leachate can be applied in the manufacture of a multitude of new materials. Although structural conservation might be desirable in some cases, it presents a limitation: batteries must be separated by cathode type before processing. Currently, there is no efficient and cost-effective separation technology for cathode materials. Therefore, LIBs recycling companies are proposing variants of hydrometallurgical processes [91–95]. These observations indicate that there is no simple solution for LIBs recycling. The design of these varied and complex materials is under constant improvement, requiring constant evolution of recycling processes. 2.3 Anode and electrolyte recovery 2.3.1 Anode recovery Not only the cathode contains valuable metals; anode materials (Fig. 7 ) also have promising characteristics, albeit with low added value compared with cathode materials [28,96,97]. Anode materials are generally disregarded in battery recycling studies because of their great abundance [97–102]. In addition to graphite, the anode may contain important metals, such as copper and lithium [99]. Currently, LIBs anodes are composed of a copper current collector and graphite (natural or synthetic). Graphite is widely used as anode material because it meets the voltage requirements of the majority of cathode materials, as well as being relatively affordable, extremely light, porous, and durable [103], some of the disadvantages of graphite is its low specific capacity and low columbic efficiency [104], affecting the performance of LIBs. Other carbon-based materials, transition metal oxides, alloy-based materials, MOFs, and their derivatives have been applied as anode [98] although the specific capacity of these materials is lower than that of graphite [104]. In the recycling of spent LIBs, residual graphite (60%) is often burned as slag or fuel because of the lack of suitable techniques for its recycling [105]. This represents a waste, given the economic and technological potential of graphite, the possibility of using the material for graphene production [100–106] and its wide application in the atomic energy industry [101]. In fact, graphite recovery can minimize the consumption of finite resources and mitigate environmental pollution, contributing to the sustainability of LIBs. The demand for graphite increases by 10%–12% per year [30] and its cost is on average U$8–13 per kilogram [31–33]. In addition to the environmental benefit of recycling graphite from LIBs, an efficient recycling method could facilitate the access of countries that depend on imports to the raw material [101–105]. Different anode recycling techniques have been proposed. The pyrometallurgical method is the most used in industrial recycling; however, it generates materials with metallic impurities [99]. The major problems associated with anode recycling lie in the separation of anode and current collector and degradation of the active material. It is necessary to develop techniques to circumvent these difficulties. Zhang et al. (2017) proposed a calcination protocol (600 °C, 1 h) for the removal of organic matter from anode graphite; the recycled graphite was used to prepare graphene [107]. Using a physical approach, He et al. (2017) investigated the recovery of LiCoO2 and graphite by flotation in the presence of Fenton reagent at a ratio of 40:280 H2O2/Fe2+ and 25:100 liquid/solid. The recovery was 98.99% [108]. Xiao et al. (2021) separated graphite and the current collector and regenerated graphite as anode by using a solution of ammonium persulfate and leaching the material at 80 °C for 1 h. The recovered graphite showed an increase in layer spacing and excellent performance in reversible lithium storage [99]. Cao et al. (2021) performed the separation of graphite and current collector by electrolysis in Na2SO4 solution. The recovered graphite had 95% purity and was reapplied as LIBs anode, exhibiting good stability during cycles, a specific discharge capacity of 427.81 mAh/g at 0.1 C, and a coulombic efficiency of 98% [109]. Nguyen et al. (2021) recovered graphite and copper foil by grinding, milling, and size separation. The carbonaceous anode material was effective in adsorption and catalysis processes of redox reactions for remediation of water and soil contaminated with lead, barium, and cadmium [110]. In the study of Zhang et al. (2018), graphite was recovered from spent batteries by calcination at 600 °C for removal of organic compounds and leaching of copper sheets with H2SO4. Subsequently, the material was used for synthesis of a graphene/copper oxide composite by absorption of copper sulfate in exfoliated graphene oxide in the presence of ethylene glycol under agitation at 150 °C for 3 h. The graphene oxide-copper composite was efficient in the photodegradation of methylene blue [111]. 2.3.2 Electrolyte recovery Another important component of LIBs is the electrolyte. Because it contains different lithium salts and volatile organic compounds, improper treatment or disposal of this waste may have adverse impacts on human health and the environment; therefore, it is necessary to develop methods for extracting this component [98–108]. Many studies have focused on CO2-assisted electrolyte recovery [108,112–114]. He et al. (2019) applied a green, environmentally friendly method for simultaneous recovery of electrolyte (containing LiPF6, ethylene carbonate, and propylene carbonate), electrodes, and current collectors. Distillation and filtration processes were used, providing a recovery efficiency of 95.6% [115]. Liu et al. (2017) presented another approach for electrolyte recycling from LIBs; it consisted of CO2 extraction and purification via resins and molecular sieves. The resulting electrolyte exhibited high ionic conductivity at 20 °C (0.19 mS/cm), very close to that of a commercial electrolyte with the same composition [112]. Zhong et al. (2019) recovered electrolytes by pyrolysis at low volatilization temperature. The lithium salt (LiPF6) was pyrolyzed, and 99.91% of organic electrolytes were recovered [116]. Because the capacity of reclaimed electrolytes decreases drastically in initial cycles, their reuse is impractical, necessitating studies on electrolyte extraction and purification [98,112]. 2.4 Applications of recycled materials Metals such as cobalt, lithium, nickel and graphite are of great importance for many processes and have high added value. Cobalt, for instance, has electrical, catalytic, magnetic, and optical characteristics that make it promising for use in biosensors, nanodevices, and electronic devices. Nanoparticles obtained from cobalt oxides find application as field-effect transistors, energy storage materials, and sensors. Cobalt nanoparticles have various biomedical applications owing to their antibacterial, anticancer, antioxidant, antifungal, and enzyme inhibition properties. The spinel cobalt oxide Co3O4 is an antiferromagnetic p-type multifunctional semiconductor. The bandgap of Co3O4 is about 1.48–2.19 eV, which makes it a suitable photocatalyst for the degradation of organic pollutants under visible light [117,118]. The final stage of recycling is the reintroduction of recycled materials for the production of new products. Materials recycled from spent LIBs are mainly used for resynthesis, that is, they are reused for their original function. The best examples of materials used in this type of recycling are cathode metallic oxides. Recycled materials may also be applied as pseudocapacitors, supercapacitors, non-enzymatic electrochemical sensors, and catalysts. 2.4.1 Resynthesis of recycled materials Li et al. (2011) carried out regeneration synthesis of LiCoO2 crystals on nickel substrate. Nitric acid was used as electrolyte, and a single constant current electrodeposition step was applied. The resulting material showed promising electrochemical properties for reuse as cathode material, with a first charge of 130.8 mAh/g and a first discharge of 127.2 mAh/g [119]. Hanisch et al. (2011) reintroduced recycled materials as components of new batteries. The aluminum current collector was separated by thermal and mechanical treatments, and a chemical process allowed for compound recovery. LiNi0.33Co0.33Mn0.33O2 electrodes were successfully recovered and applied in new battery cells [120]. Sa (2015) obtained LiNi1/3Mn1/3Co1/3O2 as a coprecipitation product. The material was found to have a discharge capacity of 158 mAh/g, showing promise as a component of LIBs cathodes [121]. Yang et al. (2017) described a method for the recovery of metals from depleted LIBs and their regeneration as cathode materials. Materials were extracted and separated using D2EHPA, lithium carbonate, and H2SO4. The regenerated material (LiNi1/3Co1/3Mn1/3O2) had microsphere morphology and lacked impurities, resulting in good electrochemical performance [122]. Liu et al. (2018) used metallurgy for the resynthesis of materials. LiNi0.5Co0.2Mn0.3O2 showed a laminar structure composed of 6 μm spheres. Electrochemical tests revealed a discharge capacity of 160.9 mAh/g at 2.5–4.3 V, with a retention capacity of 93.8% after 50 cycles. The material had good reversibility and conductivity in cyclic voltammetry and electrochemical impedance tests [123]. Zhao (2020), in a review study, reported that LiNi x Co y Mn z O2, LiCoO2, and LiFePO4 regenerated by different pretreatment and synthesis methods exhibited similar efficiencies to the respective original materials [124]. Zhang et al. (2019) restored the graphite's performance and used it again in LIBs anodes [29]. Cao et al. (2021) shows the recovery of graphite had 95% purity and was reapplied as LIBs anode, exhibiting good stability during cycles, a specific discharge capacity of 427.81 mAh/g at 0.1 °C, and a coulombic efficiency of 98% [109]. Liu et al (2022) reconstructed the structure of the graphite layer using acid treatment. The capacity of the material after 200 cycles at 0.5C was 427.9 mAh/g [125]. 2.4.2 Use of recycled materials as electrochemical sensors Gonçalves et al. (2015) used electrodeposited material on AISI 430 stainless steel substrate as a non-enzymatic electrochemical sensor for glucose detection. The material had a sensitivity of 70.2 μA/(mmol cm2) within the linear range of 1–10 mmol/L. These results are promising for the development of sensors from recycled materials [126]. The hybrid oxide reduced graphene oxide (rGO)/graphene oxide (CoO) was obtained by sol-gel synthesis and applied as an ascorbic acid sensor. Performance was satisfactory at the concentration range of 0.5 to 5 mmol/L in alkaline medium. Ribeiro et al. (2021) effectively recycled batteries using 2.0 mol/L citric acid as leaching agent and obtained a theoretical yield of 74.10% [15]. CoO was obtained by using a modified Hummers’ method [127,128], and rGO was obtained via thermal methods for electronic applications [15]. 2.4.3 Use of recycled materials as pseudocapacitors Recent studies investigated the applicability of LIBs recycling to produce metal oxides with electrochemical functionalities, such as supercapacitors and pseudocapacitors [127–132]. Barbieri et al. (2014) described the recycling of cobalt from spent LIBs cathodes. Materials were recovered in the form of β-Co(OH)2 and Co3O4 via thermal treatment. Chemical and electrochemical precipitation were used to obtain starting materials. The final products were applied to prepare electrodes containing Co3O4, carbon black, and epoxy resin, which showed high reversibility, charging efficiency, and specific capacitance (13.0 F/g at 1.0 mV/s), suggesting potential as pseudocapacitors [129]. Aboelazm et al. (2018) applied electrodeposition under a magnetic field for the formation of cobalt oxides from spent LIBs. Nanostructures were shown to have a large electroactive surface area, resulting in a material with excellent electrochemical performance and capacitive behavior. Electrochemical tests revealed a capacitive retention of 96% after 5000 cycles and charge storage of 1273 F/g to 1 A/g [130]. A paper by Natarajan presents the behavior of rGO obtained from recycling graphite from LIBs as a supercapacitor. The specific capacity was more than 112 F/g at a current density of 0.5 A/g [132]. Schiavi etaal. (2021) reports a new process that produces an asymmetric supercapacitor by completely recycling end-of-life lithium-ion batteries. The asymmetric supercapacitor assembled using recovered nanowire-based positive electrodes and graphite as negative electrodes showed a specific capacitance of 42 F/g, providing a maximum energy density of ∼9 Wh/kg and an energy density of 416 W/kg at 2.5 mA/cm2 [133]. 2.4.4 Use of recycled materials as catalysts Santana (2017) obtained LiCoO2 by using a sol-gel process at 850 °C. The compound exhibited great reversibility of lithium intercalation and deintercalation at cobalt oxide sites, which are interesting characteristics for the manufacture of LIBs cathodes. At temperatures below 850 °C, a LiCoO2/Co3O4 mixture was obtained, which was shown to be highly effective in the degradation of methylene blue (99%). Electrochemical recovery of battery metals by a chronoamperometric method afforded Co(OH)2/LiCoO2/Co3O4; the composite was subjected to supercapacitor tests [134]. Falqueto et al. (2018) used recycled cobalt from spent LIBs as catalyst for azo dye degradation. Metallic cobalt was obtained by electrodeposition (−1.1 V, 15 C/cm2, pH 2.7) in a solution leached from the cathode of spent LIBs. The material was combined with 0.27 mol/L H2O2 for azo dye degradation, affording a decolorization efficiency of 85% after 210 min under UV radiation, suggesting promising catalytic properties [135]. Rocha et al. (2019) used copper recycled from spent LIBs for the synthesis of copper ferrite (CuFe2O4). The photocatalytic properties of the material were assessed in the decolorization of methylene blue by a heterogeneous photo-Fenton process. The recycled material promoted 96.1% decolorization after 45 min of reaction [136]. In the study of Xi et al. (2020), CoFe2O4/MgO(x) ferrites were synthesized by self-combustion and sol-gel techniques from spent LIBs. Sundry parameters, such as particle size, lattice measure, microstructure, and magnetic and magnetostrictive properties, were studied. Different MgO ratios were analyzed, and it was observed that the best magnetic properties were exhibited by CoFe2O4/MgO(0.02) nanocomposites. Such materials showed promising potential as non-contact sensors and actuators with low magnetic fields [137]. 2.5 Electrocatalysis Water electrolysis is one of the most promising methods for green hydrogen generation. The process is based on the electrochemical separation of water into oxygen (anodic reaction) and hydrogen (cathodic reaction). The cathodic process, known as hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), and the anodic process, known as oxygen evolution reaction (OER), can be represented by the following general equation (Eq. (5)) [125]. (5) 2 H 2 O l → 2 H 2 ( g ) + O 2 ( g ) ( E 0 = 1.23 V v s . S H E ) The half-reactions of water electrolysis and theoretical potentials compared with a standard hydrogen electrode (SHE) depend on the pH of the electrolytic medium [125–138]. In alkaline medium, half-reactions can be represented as follows (Eqs. (6) and (7)). (6) 4 O H - → O 2 + H 2 O + 4 e - ( O E R E 0 = - 0 , 40 V v s . S H E ) (7) H 2 O + 4 e - → 2 H 2 + 4 O H - ( H E R : E 0 = - 0.83 V vs . S H E ) In acid medium, reactions proceed according to the following equations (Eqs. (8) and (9)). (8) 2 H 2 O → O 2 + 4 H + + 4 e - ( O E R : E 0 = 1.23 V v s . S H E ) (9) 4 H + + 4 e - → 2 H 2 ( H E R : E 0 = 0.00 V v s . S H E ) The cell potential of 1.23 V vs. SHE is a theoretical value for atmospheric pressure and ambient temperature (25 °C) conditions. Under experimental conditions, the operational potential of water electrolysis is the sum of the theoretical value and an overpotential (ηT). Several materials have been used as electrocatalysts to reduce the overpotential of water electrolysis (Liu et al., 2022) [125]. Materials containing noble metals such as RuO/TiO2 nano heterostructures [96], RuO2 nanoporous structures [139], IrO2 nanoparticles [140], and PtCu nanospheres [141] have good performance as electrocatalysts. Application of these materials, however, has low economic feasibility, necessitating the development of efficient, low-cost electrocatalysts not based on noble metals [142].Electroactive materials synthesized from spent LIBs have shown promise as electrocatalysts in water electrolysis. Liu and colleagues (2021) developed a cobalt nitride-graphene (CoN-Gr) hybrid catalyst with a sea urchin-like morphology for complete water electrolysis. The material was synthesized from cobalt recovered from spent LIBs cathodes. In HER electrocatalysis, the sea urchin-like catalyst showed superior activity than catalysts with other morphologies. The material showed overpotential values close to that of the reference material Pt/C. Furthermore, the electrocatalyst achieved excellent performance in OER, with an η 10 of 280 mV, which is 10 mV lower than the value obtained with RuO2. At a current density of 10 mA/cm, the (−)CoN-Gr||CoN-Gr(+) cell had a potential difference of 1.61 V, a value close to the potential difference of a Pt/C||RuO2 cell (1.6 V) [143]. Other materials obtained by LIBs recycling were used as OER electrocatalysts, such as (HT)LiCoO2 [144], LiNi0.5Mn0.3Co0.2O2 [145], and MnCo2O4 [146]. These findings demonstrate that LIBs recycling is a cornerstone for the transition to a low-carbon energy sector, as recycled materials can be used for the manufacture of new batteries for electric vehicles and applied as electrocatalysts in green hydrogen production. Fig. 8 is a schematic representation of the applications of recycled materials. 3 Industrial-scale recycling of spent LIBs Large-scale recycling may use a combination of physical separation techniques, pyrometallurgy, and hydrometallurgy. Some recyclers produce a “black mass” of active material and sell the product to third parties for hydrometallurgical or pyrometallurgical recovery, as performed by AkkuSer. In most cases, recycling processes for cathode materials are well established, given the high economic value of such materials. Here, we describe some methods for recycling large cell assemblies, such as those used in electric vehicles. The sustainability and/or recovery efficiency of battery recycling processes of leading companies was reported by Sommerville et al. (2021) [89]. The recycling process can be divided into the following steps: • Stabilization: makes the cells more inert, preventing explosions; • Opening and fragmentation: used to expose the interior of cells, giving access to cathode materials, anode materials, electrolytes, etc. • Separation processes: used to concentrate cell components into separate streams; • Material extraction: pyrometallurgical and/or hydrometallurgical processes. Cell components are divided into eight parts: shell, aluminum foil, copper foil, cathode active material, graphite, separator, electrolytic solvent, and lithium. Recycling steps can be grouped into three main groups, namely LIBs stabilization and opening, component separation, and material extraction. A generalized flowchart of the steps and industries that use these processes is shown in Fig. 9 . Large-scale recycling generally makes use of a combination of different techniques, such as pyrometallurgy, physical separation techniques, and hydrometallurgy, depending on the desired final product [89]. Complete LIBs discharge is particularly important for the recycling of large cells, such as electric car batteries. LIBs are subjected to discharging for elimination of residual energy, making the process safer for subsequent steps [89]. Battery discharge is adopted by the company Duesenfeld, which has made a name for itself by recycling EV batteries instead of individual cells [89,147]. Duesenfeld uses an inert atmosphere for LIBs fragmentation, thereby preventing the ignition of flammable components [89]. The use of inert gas during fragmentation is also part of the Recupyl stabilization process [89,148]. Inert atmospheres do not contain oxygen or moisture. Inert gases, such as CO2, react to form a lithium carbonate layer, avoiding explosion [89]. Stabilization may also be achieved by vacuum pyrolysis at 250 °C to remove electrolyte and plastics, as adopted by Accurec; grinding under a high airflow rate, as performed by AkkuSer; and wet fragmentation and cryogenic processing, as applied by Retriev. Cryogenic processing is considered a potential safety risk compared with flush stabilization because electrochemical power is not removed from cells; rather, the reaction rate is reduced [89]. Separation processes are performed to separately concentrate LIBs components. Separation may be based on size, magnetic properties, or density. Size separation is the simplest form of physical separation and is commonly used in recycling companies, except Umicore, as depicted in Fig. 9. The most common size separation method is solid-liquid filtration [89]. Magnetic separation is mainly used to remove the battery casing. This process is adopted by companies such as Accurec, AkkuSer, and Recupyl. Density separation makes it possible to separate coating materials, electrode foils, and active material [89], as applied by Accurec, Recupyl, Retriev, and Duesenfeld. Separation processes may also be combined, as performed by Accurec, which uses size, magnetic, and density separation methods. Vibrating screens and high airflow are also used to separate aluminum, copper, and active material. After separation, materials are subjected to extraction of valuable metals, a process of great socioeconomic interest. Recycling of lead–acid batteries paved the way for the extraction of valuable metals from LIBs. The recovery of lithium and other precious materials is not a simple task because of the different structures and properties of metals found in LIBs. Some industries established a recycling line for LIBs, as described in Table 2 . Currently, Umicore is the market leader in recycling electric vehicle batteries, with a capacity of 7000 t/year at the working plant in Belgium [147]. 4 Laboratory-scale recycling of LIBs 4.1 Recycling of spent LIBswith inorganic acids Fig. 10 represents the dismantling of the LIBs on a laboratory scale. Strong inorganic acids such as HCl, H2SO4, and HNO3 can be used as leaching agents for LIBs [149]. The chemical reactions of HCl and H2SO4 with a LIBs cathode composed of LiCoO2 are shown in Eqs. (10) and (11), respectively [2]. (10) 8 H C l + 2 L i C o O 2 → 2 C o C l 2 + C l 2 + 2 L i C l + 5 H 2 O (11) 3 H 2 S O 4 + 2 L i C o O 2 + 2 H 2 O 2 → L i 2 S O 4 + 5 H 2 O + 3 2 O 2 + 2 C o S O 4 Reactions using other monoprotic or polyprotic inorganic acids occur according to a similar mechanism. The leaching efficiency of the above-mentioned acids is as follows: HCl > HNO3 ≈ H2SO4. HCl has a higher leaching efficiency because of its high reducing power. For many acids, leaching efficiency can be enhanced by the use of hydrogen peroxide [2,43]. A 99% leaching efficiency for cobalt and lithium was obtained by Contestabile et al. (2001) using a 4 M HCl solution at 80 °C for 1 h [50]. Barik et al. (2017) demonstrated the industrial applicability of a recycling process that achieved 99% of leaching efficiency for Mn and Co using a 1.75 mol/L HCl solution at 50 °C for 2 h [150]. Table 3 presents some studies using inorganic acids to recycle LIBs on a laboratory scale. Many technologies have been developed or are applied on a small industrial scale at pilot plants. Although there are well-defined strategies for efficiently recovering some metals, most processes are complex and require high investment costs. The use of inorganic acids might constitute an environmental problem given the large volume of toxic effluents generated at the end reaction. An alternative to decrease environmental impacts is to use organic acids, which are biodegradable and easy to recycle [149,153]. 4.2 Recycling of spent LIBswith organic acids Organic acids such as citric, malic, oxalic, and ascorbic acids have been studied as potential substitutes for inorganic acids in recycling processes [154,155]. It is reported in the literature that citric acid has higher efficiency in leaching cobalt than inorganic acids [156]. The best dissolution conditions were found to be 90 °C in the presence of a reductant, such as H2O2 [87]. The reaction mechanism between citric acid and the LIBs cathode is described by Eq. (12) [2,156]. (12) 6 H 3 C i t ( a q ) + L i C o O 2 ( a q ) + H 2 O 2 ( a q ) → 2 L i ( a q ) + + 2 C o ( a q ) 2 + + 6 H 2 C i t ( a q ) - + H 2 O + O 2 ( a q ) The reaction mechanism is similar for most organic acids. Table 4 shows some recent studies on the use of organic acids and their metal recovery efficiency. 5 Challenges of LIBs recycling processes There are many challenges associated with battery collection, pretreatment methods, metal extraction, and application of recovered materials. Finding solutions to such barriers is crucial, as only 5% of spent LIBs are currently recycled [160–165] Some problems encountered in LIBs recycling are: • Inefficient selective collection, especially of small storage devices. In many cases, batteries are disposed of as common waste [161]. It is necessary to implement policies to raise awareness of proper disposal and ensure the availability of collection points accessible to the community. • Pretreatment processes face several problems, such as short circuits and explosions, especially in large batteries. Automated dismantling processes are needed. • Metal extraction processes are relatively expensive; only the recycling of batteries containing cobalt is economically advantageous. The presence of a mixture of metals in the battery cathode and residual lithium in the anode negatively impacts the purity of the recovered product and its added value, making most processes expensive and complex. • Most studies on recycling focus on cathode materials. Few studies address parts such as plastic casings, current collectors, electrolyte, and anode. Electrolytes are hardly mentioned because of difficulties associated with their high volatility. • The lack of popularization and subsidies to adapt recycling processes or to cover investment costs hinder the development of a circular economy. The costs of recovering secondary materials are similar to the costs of primary production [166]. • Lack of policies and regulations. Federal and state laws should mandate or encourage the storage, reuse, and recovery of LIBs, as well as limit landfill disposal. The uncertainty and vulnerability associated with LIBs reuse/recovery projects can be mitigated by clearly specified regulatory criteria and incentives [3]. LIBs recycling contributes to reducing waste disposal, mining impacts, and extraction of raw materials for the production of new batteries. Design for recycling can produce significant changes to production structures, which might stimulate a circular economy. It is necessary to establish standardized schemes that encompass all steps from LIBs production to recycling. The main goal of LIBs recycling is to achieve a sustainable, efficient, and low-cost system to process spent LIBs on an industrial scale. LIBs recycling is key to achieving sustainability in the global automotive and renewable energy sectors, but many efforts are still needed to translate laboratory methods to industrial plants. Overall, the main objective of recycling is to contribute to the innovativeness, environmental adequacy, and viability of production systems. Two approaches to recycling need to be taken into account. The first considers batteries that are already in circulation. For these products, because of the series of challenges mentioned previously, reuse and recycling methods will continue to be difficult and inefficient. The second approach is to focus on future generations of LIBs. New generations should be designed with the aim of overcoming current challenges. Prototypes of new LIBs generations should be tested for both internal consistency and recycling capacity. Recycling regulations should be enforced by governments, and companies should aim to develop a LIBs collection network [167]. Quality control is a fundamental step in any stage of these processes for early detection of problems and minimization of waste generation. Battery design also influences recycling capability. The convenience of recycling spent batteries should be considered when designing the entire cell. Collaborations between the industry and academia are very relevant and have led to many important achievements. Although academic researchers have proposed different battery recycling methods, few have been adopted by the industry, for various reasons. This relationship between the industry and academia must be strengthened, bringing laboratory processes closer to industrial processes [167,168]. His current field placement revolves around lithium-ion batteries and its recycling processes. Jessielem Ribeiro has a master's degree in science and is a doctoral student in science at the Federal University of Espírito Santo Vitória, Brazil. She works in the area of materials synthesis and electrochemistry. Her current field placement revolves around the recycling processes of Li-ion batteries, synthesis of new materials, and their applications in electronic devices. Edson Lucas Dosval Coelho is undergraduate student in chemistry at the Federal University of Espírito Santo, Vitória, Brazil. and works in the area of materials and electrochemistry. His research work focuses on the synthesis of materials recycled from spent lithium-ion batteries for advanced energy/environmental applications Marcos Benedito José Geraldo de Freitas obtained a doctorate in science from the Federal University of São Carlos and is an adjunct professor at the Federal University of Espirito Santo acting in the areas: Recycling of Li-ion batteries, metal nickel hydride, zinc-manganese oxide and nickel cadmium as a form of development sustainable; Synthesis, characterization and application of materials; Catalysis, Corrosion and inhibitors; Electrodeposition; Electrochemistry of petroleum

coredata.dc:description: Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) containing graphite as anode material and LiCoO2, LiMn2O4, and LiNi x Mn y CozO2 as cathode materials are the most used worldwide because of their high energy density, capacitance, durability, and safety. However, such widespread use implies the generation of large amounts of electronic waste. It is estimated that more than 11 million ton of LIBs waste will have been generated by 2030. Battery recycling can contribute to minimizing environmental contamination and reducing production costs through the recovery of high-value raw materials such as lithium, cobalt, and nickel. The most common processes used to recycle spent LIBs are pyrometallurgical, biometallurgical, and hydrometallurgical. Given the current scenario, it is necessary to develop environmentally friendly methods to recycle batteries and synthesize materials with multiple technological applications. This study presents a review of industrial and laboratory processes for recycling spent LIBs and producing materials that can be used in new batteries, energy storage devices, electrochemical sensors, and photocatalytic reactions.

coredata.dc:title: Recycling of spent lithium-ion batteries as a sustainable solution to obtain raw materials for different applications
